Allometry model

Jaideep Joshi

27 February 2022

theory_allometry.Rmd

Height-diameter scaling

According to the T-model, height scales with diameter as

\[H = H_{\text{m}}\left( 1 - e^{- aD/H_{\text{m}}} \right),\] \(1\)

so that \(a\) is the ratio of initial height to diameter (i.e., for seedlings with height \(H_{0}\) and diameter \(D_{0}\), \(H_{0} \approx aD_{0}\)).

Crown-area scaling

Total crown projection area scales with height and diameter as

\[A_{\text{c}} = \frac{\pi c}{4a}HD.\] \(2\)

so that \(c\) is the initial ratio of crown area to sapwood area. Since seedlings have no heartwood, \(A_{\text{c,0}} \approx c \cdot \pi D_{0}^{2}/4\).

Heartwood scaling

We define the sapwood fraction \(f_{\text{s}}\) as the fraction of the cross-sectional area that is sapwood. The ratio of the sapwood area to leaf area is the Huber Value, \(\nu_{\text{H}}\), and the ratio of leaf area to crown area is the crown leaf area index, \(L\). Then, the ratio of sapwood area to crown area is

\[\frac{A_{\text{s}}}{A_{\text{c}}} = \frac{A_{\text{s}}}{A_{\text{l}}} \cdot \frac{A_{\text{l}}}{A_{\text{c}}} = \nu_{\text{H}}L.\]

Sapwood area is therefore given by

\[A_{\text{s}} = \nu_{\text{H}}LA_{c} = \nu_{\text{H}}Lc\left( \frac{\pi}{4}D^{2} \right)\frac{H}{aD}.\]

The sapwood fraction is then

\[f_{\text{s}} = \frac{A_{\text{s}}}{A_{\text{base}}} = \nu_{\text{H}}Lc\frac{H}{aD}.\]

Assuming that the sapwood is concentrated within a thin annulus of width \(w_{\text{s}}\) at the edge of the stem, the sapwood area is \(A_{\text{s}} = \pi Dw_{\text{s}}\). The sapwood width is therefore,

\[w_{\text{s}} = \frac{1}{\pi D}\nu_{\text{H}}Lc\left( \frac{\pi}{4}D^{2} \right)\frac{H}{aD} = \frac{\nu_{\text{H}}Lc}{4a}H = \frac{f_{\text{s}}}{4}D.\] \(3\)

Empirical evidence shows that the sapwood width initially increases with age and then saturates.

To define the heartwood allometry, we consider two possibilities, in which either sapwood-fraction, or the ratio of sapwood-area to crown-area, is constant throughout the lifetime of the plant, i.e., it is independent of the plant geometry. The first possibility (\(f_{\text{s}} = \text{constant}\)) implies that sapwood width scales with diameter, and thus increases with age. The second possibility (\(\frac{A_{\text{s}}}{A_{\text{c}}} = \text{constant}\)) implies that sapwood width scales with height, and thus increases initially with age and then saturates. Empirical evidence is consistent with this second possibility. To find the value of \(\frac{A_{\text{s}}}{A_{\text{c}}}\), we note that in young trees, \(H = aD\) and \(f_{\text{s}} = 1\). Substituting in Eq. (3), we get

\[\nu_{\text{H}}L = 1/c.\]

and

\[f_{\text{s}} = H/aD.\]

Fine root scaling

We assume that fine root mass scales instantaneously with leaf area as

\[m_{\text{r}} = \zeta A_{\text{l}} = \zeta LA_{\text{c}}.\]

This instantaneous scaling implies that leaves and fine roots are controlled simultaneously even on shorter timescales associated with the control of leaf area, and if leaves are shed, fine roots are lost we well.

Coarse root scaling

We assume that coarse root mass scales with stem mass as

\[m_{\text{cr}} = f_{\text{cr}}m_{\text{w}}.\]
